Journal.Title: Journal of the science of food and agriculture

Article.ArticleTitle: Postharvest gaseous ozone treatment enhances quality parameters and delays softening in cantaloupe melon during storage at 6 °C.

AbstractText: A trial was conducted to evaluate the effect of postharvest gaseous ozone (O<sub>3</sub> ) treatment on quality parameters and cell wall enzymes of cantaloupe melon cv. Caldeo during storage at 6 °C for 13 days. Fruits were kept in cold storage and treated with 0.15 ppm gaseous O<sub>3</sub> during the day and 0.3 ppm overnight; control fruits (CK) were stored in normal atmosphere.

Firmness was higher and ethylene concentration significantly lower in O<sub>3</sub> fruits compared with CK fruits. During storage, microbial counts were lower in both O<sub>3</sub> and CK fruits; from day 9, O<sub>3</sub> fruits showed a significant decrease in mesophilic aerobes. Additionally, total carotenoids had a tendency to be higher, with no significant differences between CK and O<sub>3</sub> fruits. The same trend was observed for ascorbic acid, colour, total soluble solids content and acidity. Finally, O<sub>3</sub> treatment reduced the activities of cell wall enzymes α-arabinopyranosidase, β-galactopyranosidase and polygalacturonase starting from day 3 of storage. Pectin methyl esterase activity did not seem to be affected by O<sub>3</sub> treatment.

Gaseous O<sub>3</sub> treatment during cold storage was effective in decreasing ethylene production and delaying fruit softening in cantaloupe melon by extending quality maintenance. © 2017 Society of Chemical Industry.
